Reducing this emergency to a quip about variants or transmission not only fails to educate the public about the complexity of the crisis, but does a tremendous disservice to the people who have lost their lives.

I'm no expert in complex systems analysis, but you don't have to be to understand that "double mutants" or what WHO has tweeted are grossly oversimplified and do not adequately explain a national public health disaster (nor should they be used to advance personal agendas).

The reality is more complex. It's many factors: failed leadership, misplaced priorities, lack of access to health care, PPE, vaccines, lack of epi data to guide evidence-based policy, demographics, epidemiology, misinformation.

So what's the point of all this? Well, I've been more and more pissed off by hot takes attributing this tragedy to individual factors that are either beyond our control (variants) or the fault of specific people (WHO didn't say it was airborne) or misinformation (herd immunity).

The present situation demonstrates clearly that this model's estimates were extraordinarily incorrect, and one more example of what I've taken to calling "catastrophic optimism." Optimism is important, but not at the expense of necessary precautions. https://t.co/rExgj1aElY

So it's a crucial safety measure to ensure there is no RCA in a vaccine preparation. The 1 RCA/30 billion particles FDA standard ensures that there is essentially NO RCA in viral vectored vaccines. Gamaleya is arguing that some higher but unquantifiable amount is...sure, okay!

And while Ad5 usually does cause common colds as a respiratory pathogen in most people, this does present a safety issue for some, particularly for people who are immunocompromised. People can die from adenovirus infections. https://t.co/hM0reFRzdH

Why does this matter? That doesn't sound like a lot. And doesn't Ad5 just cause minor colds anyway? Well, it matters because that's the thing about replication-competent viruses: they replicate exponentially. So 10 viruses can become 100, 1000, 10000, 100000...you get the idea.

So Sputnik's makers are splitting technical hairs to get around acknowledging that each dose of Ad5 vaccine has 0-99 RCAs in it. They are arguing that this is still way below the (comparatively very high) threshold that they arbitrarily set for residual RCAs.

So I think Anvisa read between the lines. "Less than 100 RCAs/dose" means there WERE plaques detected, but so few that they couldn't accurately quantify RCA titer. If they detected nothing, they would have listed this as "NOT DETECTED" like they did for placebo.

The 100 RCA cutoff is thus conveniently set at the lower limit of what you can accurately measure using the plaque assay. But the assay detects less virus than that, though it can't be accurately quantified. Just 1 plaque (~10 RCAs) means there's replication competent virus there

As Dr. Racaniello explains, you count plaques at the dilution that gives between 10-100 plaques. This means that undiluted vaccine on a plate (a 10X dilution) needs to produce at least 10 plaques to accurately determine infectious titer. So 10 plaques on a 1:10 dilution=100 PFU. https://t.co/Q3lP1ZWfMX

So why this weird measurement? "Less than 100 RCAs /dose" doesn't sound like an actual quantity. Time for some virologist scrutiny. The limit of detection for the plaque assay is 100 plaque forming units (PFUs), because this is the cutoff for accurately quantifying PFUs.
But the vaccine RCAs were reported as "less than 100 RCAs/dose". That's a little different than "NOT DETECTED" and sure sounds like they saw plaques in their plaque assay! https://t.co/iuN7SLLiAi
